articles.headline: A Drone Strike and Dwindling Hope
articles.snippet: The area of Pakistan where David Rohde, a Times reporter, and two Afghan colleagues were held for months was frequently hit by missiles fired from American drones.
articles.abstract: The area of Pakistan where David Rohde, a Times reporter, and two Afghan colleagues were held for months was frequently hit by missiles fired from American drones.
articles.lead_paragraph: TWO deafening explosions shook the walls of the compound where the Taliban held us hostage. My guards and I dived to the floor as chunks of dirt hurtled through the window.

articles.headline: Credit Suisse Overhauls Compensation
articles.snippet: While many banks are discussing changes, Credit Suisse’s plan puts it in line with pay practices endorsed by the Group of 20 nations.
articles.abstract: While many banks are discussing changes, Credit Suisse’s plan puts it in line with pay practices endorsed by the Group of 20 nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Wall Street looks forward to a new era of blowout bonuses, the unthinkable is happening, at least at Credit Suisse, the big Swiss bank. It said on Tuesday that it would radically change the way it paid its employees.

articles.headline: For Car Buyers, the Brand Romance Is Gone
articles.snippet: Only 20 percent of new-car buyers this year have stayed with their previous brand, a reversal of shopping trends from decades ago.
articles.abstract: Only 20 percent of new-car buyers this year have stayed with their previous brand, a reversal of shopping trends from decades ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  To sell a car in the 1980s, dealers had to do little more than open their doors, and loyal buyers would show up to trade in their Chevrolet for a new Chevrolet, or their Toyota for another Toyota.

articles.headline: A Deal That Lost Millions for Galleon
articles.snippet: One bad trade more than wiped out the profits that prosecutors claim Raj Rajaratnam and his accomplices reaped with their scheme.
articles.abstract: One bad trade more than wiped out the profits that prosecutors claim Raj Rajaratnam and his accomplices reaped with their scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: Raj Rajaratnam, the authorities say, masterminded one of the biggest insider-trading schemes in a generation.

articles.headline: Volcker Fails to Sell a Bank Strategy
articles.snippet: The White House seems averse to the former Fed chief’s call to separate banks from risky Wall Street trading.
articles.abstract: The White House seems averse to the former Fed chief’s call to separate banks from risky Wall Street trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: Listen to a top economist in the Obama administration describe Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman who endorsed Mr. Obama early in his election campaign and who stood by his side during the financial crisis.

articles.headline: E-Book Fans Keep Format in Spotlight
articles.snippet: Book sellers are making the case that people are reading more because of e-books.
articles.abstract: Book sellers are making the case that people are reading more because of e-books.
articles.lead_paragraph: The publishing industry has been under a dark cloud recently.

articles.headline: One Reporter’s Lonely Beat, Witnessing Executions
articles.snippet: As newsrooms shrink, Michael Graczyk, an A.P. reporter, often provides the only account of an execution.
articles.abstract: As newsrooms shrink, Michael Graczyk, an A.P. reporter, often provides the only account of an execution.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of all the consequences of shrinking newsrooms, one of the oddest is this: Fewer journalists are available to watch people die. But Michael Graczyk has witnessed more than 300 deaths, and many of those were people he had come to know.

articles.headline: Rising Debt a Threat to Japanese Economy
articles.snippet: The question of how much debt a country can carry looms large in the U.S., but even larger in Japan.
articles.abstract: The question of how much debt a country can carry looms large in the U.S., but even larger in Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  How much debt can an industrialized country carry before the nation’s economy and its currency bow, then break?
